That's a great connection to make! Understanding the materials and techniques used in art can indeed enhance your appreciation and skills as an artist. Life drawing classes are an excellent way to develop your observational skills, and with a newfound appreciation for the conservation process, you might find yourself paying closer attention to the textures, colors, and layering in your own work.

As an artist, you might be interested to know that many art conservators start their careers as artists or art historians, and then transition into conservation. The skills you develop in life drawing, such as attention to detail, observation, and an understanding of color theory, can be valuable assets in the field of art conservation.

Moreover, understanding the materials and techniques used in art can also inform your own creative decisions as an artist. By learning about the properties of different pigments, binders, and substrates, you can experiment with new mediums and techniques, pushing the boundaries of your own artistic expression.

Remember, art conservation is not just about preserving the past; it's also about understanding the artistic process and the materials used to create the artworks. By appreciating the intricacies of art conservation, you can gain a deeper respect for the art-making process and the artists who came before us.

Enjoy your life drawing class, and who knows, maybe you'll discover a new passion for art conservation!
